Message.Title: Intel is becoming a growth stock
Message.Msg: Intel has entered or will enter into these new markets: - Smartphones - baseband - Foundry - Web TV - Solid-State Drives Revenues from these market are really "icing on the cake" as they will utilized manufacturing process already paid for by Intel's core products. For example, all the FABS that are producing Medfield/Clovertrail 32nm wafers would have been paid for by 32nm Sandy Bridge. All the 22nm FABS that will produce BayTrail would have been paid for by Ivy Bridge and Haswell. This is a major advantage Intel has over arm foundries and partners. It's important to note that revenue from these new markets are in *addition* to their other products, i.e., they're not cannibalizing other sales. Example: Apple may have cannibalized some of it's own iPad margins by introducing the lower margin iPad Mini.. But Intel selling smartphone chips (at less margin) is not taking business away from any other Intel division. So how is adding lower margin sales a bad thing when they are in *addition* to all other sales? Answer is they're not. Intel is going to grow BIG TIME.

Message.Title: The Bull Case for Intel
Message.Msg: Engineering wins, entailing superior performance and power consumption, will allow Intel chips to be sold even at a price premium to ARM derivatives. Intel is boasting that it has busted the “x86 power myth”, that is ARM devices are necessarily more power-saving at the same performance level. This is supported by a comparison from ABI Research, in addition to a side-by-side comparison of the Samsung ATIV Smart PC vs. Microsoft Surface RT by Anandtech. ABI found that “Intel’s [Clover Trail+] chip drew 0.85A of average current vs. 1.38A for the Samsung Exynos Octa, and 1.79A for the Qualcomm APQ8064T.” Anandtech was able to squeeze out a “17% battery life advantage, despite the 3% smaller battery” while web-browsing on the Intel-based Samsung ATIV compared to the ARM-powered Surface RT. Dual-boot devices running a full version of Windows 8 (non-RT) and Android, which is not possible with ARM, will become popularized. This would galvanize demand for Intel Clover Trail chips and beyond, which have this capability From mobilex86

Message.Title: INTEL looking real good!
Message.Msg: - Haswell making big waves with all day battery life and better than retina displays. Examples include the MacBook Airs, Samsung ATIV Q, Samsung ATIV Book 9 Plus, Asus Transformer Book Trio and Dell XPS 11 - Haswell Y-series parts coming up. HP already announce they will release a fanless tablet using the Y-series. Acer is also rumored to have a Haswell Y-series tablet named 'Bulgari' - Intel's 2for1 value proposition play picking up steam. The Lenovo Yoga was a tremendous hit. Other hybrid with detachable form factors such as the Lenovo Helix are getting rave reviews. Now, the Asus Transformer Book Trio and Samsung ATIV Q are taking hybrids to the next level by introducing "Dual Boot". These devices can run both Android and Windows 8 at the same time. - Bay Trail tablets and 2for1 devices are about to explode into the market. Bay Trail offer "twice the performance at the same power level or 4.3x less power at the same performance" compared to projected competitors including the snapdragon 800. Tablets with Intel inside will have a distinct competitive advantage over those that don't. - Intel now has an LTE solution. With the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 win, Intel also announce that the tablet will come "equipped with Intel's XMM 6262 3G modem solution or Intel's XMM 7160 4G LTE solution". "Intel's XMM 7160 is one of the world's smallest and lowest-power multimode-multiband LTE solutions". With this news, it meansIntel will be able to equip all their future phones/tablets/hybrids/ultrabooks with LTE capability.

Message.Title: 15 milliseconds ahead of the official release time for the data: Intel is way too fast now?? lol
Message.Msg: The SEC is investigating the relationship between the news organization Thomson Reuters (Toronto Stock Exchange: TRI-CA) and the Institute for Supply Management, CNBC has learned. The two entities join forces to publish market-moving manufacturing data that is generated by ISM and published to high-speed data clients by Thomson Reuters. CNBC reported earlier this month that ISM's manufacturing data was inadvertently sent out early by Thomson Reuters on June 3rd to its high-speed clients, many of whom immediately traded on the information. There was a sharp market reaction to that burst of trading, which prompted downward moves in the SPY ETF, which serves as an investing tool for traders to bet on the overall direction of the market. That downward surge came 15 milliseconds ahead of the official release time for the data. In an era of super-fast computer trading, 15 milliseconds is more than enough time to profit from early knowledge of market moving information.

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: Stocks have had three consecutive sessions of nice gains. However, the technical pictures of the major indexes still aren't pretty. Both the DJIA and the S&P 500 were capped below their 50-day moving average at the close yesterday. Volume has been contracting on the upside. The S&P 500 would need to break above the 1650 area to suggest a possible end to the down-leg started on May 22. Todays quarter-end adjustment is likely to bring big volume. Beyond that, expect trading to slow and stocks to go sideways into the holiday and the June jobs report.

Message.Title: Two dishonest derivative players!
Message.Msg: Look at the tell signs on both the NASDAQ/NYSE. What is happening is stagnation in the major indices. This happens when the large derivative players are shifting their positions. They are now moving money and are going to bet against both markets. In the past this is when large corrections take place (over 10 percent). The large derivative players are the ones that run the indices. For example look at Warren Buffet; he is a heavy derivative player that has, over the last five years, substantially decreased his position in stocks and gone the derivative route. Smart, rich player. Derivative are an easy way to hide money.......so large losses can be covered up. The SEC does not understand this and they cannot track this. The result is no regulation. It will only take one major, dishonest derivative player to send our financial systems into ruin.

Topic.Title: Two dishonest derivative players!

Message.Msg: This seems to be a copy/paste of the last 5 identical threads you have started in the last 2 weeks. I would like some more detail to give this the weight you think it deserves. You say "look at the tell tale signs" .... what signs? You say "stagnation in the major indices" .... by what metric? You say this happens "when large derivative players are shifting their positions" ... how do you measure that? How can you tell they are "moving their money" so I can look for a cause and effect relationship you suggest? Warren Buffet plays derivatives through his insurance businesses but those are either reinsured or hedged. The credit default swaps clearinghouse does not show any unusual activity. What specifically are you looking at that makes you so fearful. Where, for example, do you think that Buffett is unhedged? I would like to do some DD on what you are saying but it makes no sense.

Message.Title: Investors Will Become Wealthy This Summer with This Stock!
Message.Msg: Nothing is hotter on Wall Street today than Big Data. Not only are Tableau (DATA) and Splunk (SPLK) currently up 82% and 176% from their IPOs already, both they're both trading at incredible multiples of 22X sales, despite not yet being profitable. Venture capital funds are pouring into Big Data start-ups on a daily basis - with Accel (who funded Facebook) launching their second $100mm Big Data Fund last week! You won't believe this but there is one undiscovered public Big Data Gem that is already extremely profitable and cash flow positive, and paying a big dividend, yet it's currently being valued with an enterprise value of 0.69X revenues and 6X cash flow! It has a huge cash position, no debt, and pays a 6.3% cash dividend yield! Research Concurrent (CCUR) immediately, it is perhaps the most experienced Big Data stock on Wall Street - with their Big Data clients including Time Warner Cable (TWC), Charter, Cox, Rogers, and Bright House. CCUR is allowing pay-TV operators to use Big Data to launch ad campaigns that follow users from TV to the web, while stopping users from migrating to Netflix. TWC (America's 2nd largest cable TV operator) has been using CCUR's Big Data Analytics solutions to determine the course of both their marketing efforts and network infrastructure! CCUR's EPS last quarter was up 175% year-over-year, and CCUR has successfully increased revenues, gross profits, operating income, and net income - every single quarter-after-quarter for 12 straight months! CCUR recently signed Virgin Media, the leading UK cable TV operator, as its brand new client - and doubled its cash dividend size! A business valuation of just 2X sales will only be a small fraction of the multiples DATA and SPLK are trading at, yet it'll value CCUR at $17 per share, up 125% from yesterday's close of $7.57!

Topic.Title: Shorts scream, "I told you so!" Longs cry, "Buy on the dips!" Neither matter today...

Message.Msg: I'm hoping for an attitude adjustment from the Q2 earnings. I want to see a modest beat, obviously bigger is better, a full pipeline, and some more design wins. I don't expect any new, big announcements like Apple, but a couple more tablets from Samsung, ASUS, and Lenovo would be nice. Raised guidance would be nice so the shorts start covering. We have been range bound for over a decade, so recognition that a fundamental shift in computing is underway would also be nice. The traditional PC, laptop, and server market has transformed into: PC, server, micro-server, photonic server, NUC, tablet, phablet, laptop (ultabook), all-in-one, and smart phone. Did I leave anything out?

Topic.Title: TSMC and Apple Rumor

Message.Msg: 20nm risk lots have already hit the street. I don't have 20nm benchmark numbers but I can tell you silicon is correlating which means it is meeting expectations based on simulations. We will see FinFET risk lots next year but you are right, we will not see 14nm FinFETs in mobile devices until 2015. Intel will probably be first into products but the fabless guys will be close behind and in much higher volumes. The real challenge I see for 14nm is the glut of capacity. If everybody yields there is going to be a 2X+ capacity overage. That will be good for Samsung since they are used to dumping (DRAM). TSMC will be okay with lower margins but the rest of the foundries will struggle. Intel I'm not sure about. They are a high margin company. Will they be happy in a low margin ultra competitive mobile SoC business?

Topic.Title: The Bull Case for Intel

Message.Msg: The best bull markets have a simple thesis that everyone can understand and which can be communicated in one or two sentences. We're not at that point yet. The thesis behind Intel is still too eggheady for the average joe. It took me a couple of days just to figure out finfets and trigates were the same thing. Half-node, gate first, gate last --- oh boy, whenever I see a bull argument loaded down with this stuff, I know the train has barely left the station. Ashraf had a series of articles about gross margins that was way too MENSA. Not his fault, he had to defend himself against attack and everything tumbled into the deep end of the pool. But look at the mobile bull market which has helped ARM's stock price over the past few years. Major thesis: "The PC is dead" "Mobile is the future." "Intel can't produce power efficient chips" --- very, very simple slogans which are backed by cherrypicked data. Bull markets are deductive. You have an overarching thesis or paradigm that controls what information gets through. On the other hand, when a stock is fighting out of a hole or bear market, it is entirely an inductive process of slowly building up datapoints which will complete a picture that makes sense. That's where we are with Intel. Early, early stages. The sloganeering phase has not yet started, but it will. Then we will be off to the races. When I buy a stock, I'm not interested in selling it at a rational price but at an IRRATIONALLY HIGH price.

Message.Title: Intel Sees Faster, More Flexible Future
Message.Msg: Yahoo won't let me post this...but VERY interesting article

Topic.Title: Intel Sees Faster, More Flexible Future

Message.Msg: wbmw's commentary from ihub: Quote: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- He disclosed that Intel has been working to offer customers blocks of specialized circuitry, along with its processors, so they can mix and match different combinations to create customizeable chips for their products. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- One of the more interesting pieces was left out of your bold text. This implies that Intel would be willing to offer customers use of their manufacturing to build products with Intel IP, as well as "specialized circuitry" - i.e. 3rd party IP. So if Samsung or Apple wants to build a processor with Airmont core, plus their own internal media or imaging block, built on an Intel 14nm process - it might be possible. That would be HUGE towards winning some of these big customers, IMO. And it would mean that Apple or Samsung gets to keep their huge base of designers to keep their business advantage and unique value add, while still leveraging the best of Intel's assets, and Intel gets to charge a premium for their process PLUS their IP. Again - a potential HUGE business move.

Topic.Title: TSMC and Apple Rumor

Message.Msg: "20nm risk lots have already hit the street. I don't have 20nm benchmark numbers but I can tell you silicon is correlating which means it is meeting expectations based on simulations." [28nm is still not fully ramped and here you are making mindless projections about 20nm based on "risk lots". Instead of "risk lots", it should be "lots of risk". Because that's what it is for foundry customers. It's a train wreck waiting to happen. Congestion at 20nm is going to destroy ARM when it arrives in that it will arrive at something substantially below volume production and without any indication when it will be available in volume. Just like 28nm except 20nm is much more complex and difficult. For Qualcomm, AMD, Nvidia and Apple is going to be their worst nightmare because there simply won't be enough to go around. As far as ARM FinFET goes, don't waste our time - it's too far in the future with too many unknowns to even think about yet.] [Still ARM should be perfectly okay because no one really knows that ARM's roadmap is a disaster. Oh, wait - ARM is down 70 cents today and $14.38 since its recent 52-week high. I guess the word is getting out...]

Topic.Title: What is up with this stock?

Message.Msg: Sometimes they show bullriding on ESPN. It doesn't look pleasant. Up and down and spinning to the left and then spinning to the right. The bull is trying his damndest to throw the rider and most of the time they succeed. Some CEOs try to tame the bull so that it's easier to ride. Jack Welch was famous for this at GE. He would hide some profits from exceedingly good quarters, and then sprinkle it on future quarters whenever needed. It's called "managed earnings" and is generally frowned upon.

Message.Title: Intel TV Service
Message.Msg: Looks like Krzanich is not fully convinced the Intel TV service is viable. SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Intel Corp's top executives said on Friday the microprocessor company would speed up development and roll-out of its Atom chips for mobile devices, as the computing world moves away from the traditional personal computer. The company is also being "cautious" on its Intel television service, as it continues to look at the business model, according to the company's new Chief Executive Officer Brian Krzanich.

Topic.Title: Markets Will End Green Today

Message.Msg: Well, not so much, just the NASDQ, and that barely, what with the SQQQ popping from 28.20 to 28.80 in the last twenty minutes. May 1 to June 30 and the indexes are essentially flat with a lot of volatility in the interim.

Topic.Title: Intel TV Service

Message.Msg: A couple of months ago, there was talk/rumors of Viacom (includes CBS/Paramount/Showtime) and TimeWarner (includes HBO) wanting to work with Intel Media. When you have 2 of the top 4 media conglomerates on Intel's side, I saw potential with Intel Media. Engadget (March 2013): "According to Bloomberg, Intel is getting close to offering such a service and is reportedly closing in on deals with Time Warner, Viacom and NBC that would allow them to offer both live and on-demand content over the internet. Sources are reporting that the broad terms of the deal have been agreed to, and its only a few fine details and some financial terms that need to be finalized. Intel is also allegedly in talks with Disney, CBS and News Corp. Though, those negotiations are in the preliminary stages. If Intel can successfully land deals for CNN, Comedy Central, MTV and other properties owned by its supposed new partners then its TV experiment could stand a legitimate chance at success." Now I hear about hostility from cable operators. Time Warner seems to be reasserting its ability to go it alone after spectacular successes (Superman and Game of Thrones' Red Wedding Episode which is the top watercooler event of the world of TV.) I don't know anymore if Intel Media is a good idea. It needs to have the content companies on its side for this to work. No way can Intel brute force its way to success in this sector.

Topic.Title: Intel Technology Chief Rattner quits (Why didn't Wallisweaver report this?)

Message.Msg: Intel CTO Justin Rattner steps down after hitting age limit CHIPMAKER Intel is looking for another CTO after Justin Rattner has been forced to stand down after reaching age 65. Intel's company policy is that no employee over the age of 65 can hold a corporate officer position. That means the company has to replace its CTO, with Rattner taking personal leave and the firm finding another position for him when he returns. [ghost_Fudd couldn't figure this out for himself? No surprise...]

Message.Title: B.K. is right
Message.Msg: On the subject of Intel Media: “We’re being cautious. We’re experts in silicon, we’re experts in mobility, in driving Moore’s law,” Krzanich said. “But we are not experts in the content industry and we’re being careful.” I like a CEO who knows what the core of the company is and won't stray from it unless an outrageously fortuitous opportunity arises. If the major media conglomerates come to Intel and say, "Please help us distribute our content so that we can fend off the threat of Netflix and Amazon Prime" and are willing to make it a profitable venture, then pursue it by all means. However, it looks like that is no longer the case (or never was the case) and the Intel Media Project will be like pulling teeth trying to get content. It's looking like a loser. B.K. is looking good with the above quote. It's very bullish for Intel to have a CEO who focuses the company on what they are really good at.

Topic.Title: B.K. is right

Message.Msg: You have translated his comment of saying he is being careful to mean that he is pulling out of the project. This is a non-supportable reach. He would be an idiot not to be careful. And to say that Intel went into this thinking it would be easy to get content and now wants to run in the other direction having found out otherwise is ridiculous. Intel knew it would be difficult. Is it more difficult than kicking ARM to the curb? Doubtful. So, Intel doesn't mind difficult. Nor do they mind small incremental progress as long as they consistently move ahead with their game plan. To say that they will now just cut and run is to misjudge the culture. The project is just getting started. It is not looking like a loser. It's not looking like anything but a start-up. If you think monumental start-up projects all get instant traction or die then you are naive about the nature of them. In other words, it is much too early to be drawing conclusions about its success or failure. You and the other critics on the board should give it a rest until more information is available.

Message.Title: Intel's new CEO focused on mobile chips, cautious on TV
Message.Msg: Good Reuters article. Sounds like some sort of Intel wearable device coming before the end of year: Krzanich, who mentioned he had Google's Glass wearable device in his knapsack, said computing in the next few years would focus more on items for eyes and ears, as well as wristbands and watches. "I think you'll start to see stuff with our silicon toward the end of the year and the beginning of next year," Krzanich said. "We're trying to get our silicon into some of them, create some ourselves, understand the usage and create an ecosystem."

Message.Title: Intel Vows to Pick Up Mobile Pace
Message.Msg: Intel's new leaders on Friday vowed to step up the chip maker's long-delayed penetration of mobile devices and other new product categories, starting by giving its inexpensive Atom chip equal billing with its pricier Core line. In another area, the company's new chief executive, Brian Krzanich, sounded a more cautious note about Intel's new plans to sell a set-top box and associated content service to deliver videos over the Internet. "We believe from a technology standpoint we've built a game-changing device," Mr. Krzanich said, in his first meeting with reporters since taking over the CEO post in May. But he acknowledged that the success of the service comes down to licensing attractive programming content, a field where Intel is not an influential or experienced player. "We are trying to evaluate what do we do now, and how do we best utilize this technology--and what is our business model," Mr. Krzanich said. "We are just being cautious." As for Intel's Atom chip line, originally sold for low-priced laptops called netbooks, it has been updated by the company for use in devices like smartphones and tablets. Some manufacturers have adopted Atoms already, but many more companies use rival chip designs based on technology licensed by ARM. The Core line of chips, which is used in personal computers, has long been considered Intel's flagship product line. For one thing, Core models sell for more than $100 while Atoms are closer to the $20 mark. But Renee James, Intel's newly appointed president, told reporters that the company's new strategy is based on putting Atom "on a level playing field" with Core. From the Wall Street Journal

Topic.Title: Intel Vows to Pick Up Mobile Pace

Message.Msg: Continued: Among other things, that means that Intel will begin using the company's most advanced manufacturing processes sooner to produce the Atom chip, which will help drive down its power consumption, boost its performance and reduce the cost to make it. Up until now, Core chips typically got first access to new Intel manufacturing recipes. Mr. Krzanich gave new details of plans to use the Atom technology and other new building block components to step up the company's new "foundry" business, which makes chips for other companies. He disclosed that Intel has been working to offer customers blocks of specialized circuitry, along with its processors, so they can mix and match different combinations to create customizable chips for their products. While expecting to stick mainly with Intel's longtime-processor technology, Mr. Krzanich said he would not rule out building chips for major foundry customers who prefer ARM technology. "We will consider what it takes to land customers," Ms. James said. From the Wall Street Journal

Topic.Title: Intel's new CEO focused on mobile chips, cautious on TV

Message.Msg: B.K has a slightly different view on foundry business than P.O: "If there was a great customer that we had a great relationship with laptops and other mobile devices, and they said look, we'd really love you to build our ARM-based product, we'd consider it. It depends on how strategic they are," Krzanich said.

Topic.Title: TSMC and Apple Rumor

Message.Msg: "FYI 28nm was 24% of TSMC revenue last quarter. If that is not a fully ramped node maybe you can provide a better definition?" [One that meets customer demands. This one doesn't...] Incorrect. Do not confuse capacity with ramp. TSMC 28nm is yielding 90% right now. TSMC has 90% 28nm market share. You are an accountant, read the quarterly reports and do the math. 28nm ramped faster than previous nodes by a long shot.

Topic.Title: Apple Intel deal on phones coming. Apple has no choice.

Message.Msg: TSMC's 20nm will happen in late 2014 (maybe). They are still working on 28nm HPM.

Topic.Title: TSMC and Apple Rumor

Message.Msg: "incorrect. Do not confuse capacity with ramp. TSMC 28nm is yielding 90% right now. TSMC has 90% 28nm market share. You are an accountant, read the quarterly reports and do the math. 28nm ramped faster than previous nodes by a long shot." [You are being disingenuous. The goal is obviously meeting customer demand. If you can't the customers tend to want to go someplace else. You can congratulate yourself on the current 28nm yield all you want but the bottom line is that they didn't have capacity when their customers needed it and still don't. And the same thing is going to happen at 20nm, only worse...]

Topic.Title: TSMC and Apple Rumor

Message.Msg: "TSMC has 90% 28nm market share." [You say this like it's a good thing when it is not. It's a clear sign that the ARM fabless model is totally broken. At 28nm there is really only one choice for ARM shops. One shop with insufficient capacity. It's okay by me. It just provides Intel with many new opportunities to take business away from the ARM ecosystem. This illustrates just one of the 16 reasons why ARM's fabrication is toast...]

Topic.Title: Apple Intel deal on phones coming. Apple has no choice.

Message.Msg: Is the buzz about the SRAM-based chip? Samsung Tapes Out First 14nm FinFET Test Chips. Samsung Reaches 14nm FinFET Process Technology Development Milestone [12/20/2012 08:06 PM] by Anton Shilov "...As part of its 14nm FinFET development process, Samsung, and its ecosystem partners – ARM, Cadence, Mentor and Synopsys – taped out multiple test chips ranging from a full ARM Cortex-A7 processor implementation to a SRAM-based chip capable of operation near threshold voltage levels as well as an array of analog IP."

Topic.Title: Apple Intel deal on phones coming. Apple has no choice.

Message.Msg: April 2013 Our outlook for both foundry and logic segments has not substantively changed either. Investments for 28-nanometer capacity have been strong, and we expect that to continue over the next 1 or 2 quarters prior to decelerating and broadening the number of customers in the second half of the year. The 20-nanometer investment should commence in earnest around that same time, with an estimated 30,000 to 50,000 wafer starts of capacity shipped to our customers by the end of 2013 across the industry. In the logic space, the second half story appears to represent a strengthening of original equipment additions, at least in our served markets, compared to the first half of the year. In this environment, Lam is executing our multiyear growth strategies in etch, deposition, clean and our installed base business.
